choices.B: Encapsulation ensures that classes can be designed so that their methods are inheritable.
choices.A: Encapsulation ensures that classes can be designed so that only certain fields and methods of an object are accessible from other objects.
choices.D: Encapsulation ensures that classes can be designed so that if a method has an argument MyType x, any subclass of MyType can be passed to that method.
choices.C: Encapsulation ensures that classes can be designed with some fields and methods declared as abstract.

Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is the letter D, notice that he printed the D before breaking. In the OCA exam they have questions where they change a variable or code letter to have a different answer, be careful not to memorize questions and mark them wrong in the tests, the secret is to understand how the code works to get right the questions that are variations of the code in question.

Was confused on this one so an explanation in case anyone else is stuck!
Because case "sat" doesn't have a break statement it then falls through the rest of the cases until it reaches a break. Therefore it hits the case "sun" statement, performs the subtraction of 1 and then breaks.
So as it loops you get: Sun (wd=-1), Mon (wd=-2), Wed (wd=0), Sat (wd=-1)

Selected Answer: C
The answer is the letter C, the compilation fails because the variable "wd" is an instance variable and is not local, instance variables to receive additions of values inside a static method need to be static, as it is not, the code failure.
